channel.title: Motherboard
channel.description:
So I am trying to design a moderate high end computer for my older brother..
I can get all the parts easily enough I just need a motherboard that fits my needs.
-I am looking at 12-16 gb of memory(prefer 4-6 slots for memory!) -I am looking for a board that can hold the faster memory (2100 ish? ) -I am looking for a board that can hold the newer graphic chips...(maybe gtx 640 +...also an afterthought perhaps one that can hold the older ones from like gtx 640 plus but I want it to be able to also sufficiently use a gtx titan cause I plan to buy one of those in probably half a year when the price goes down.) -I am looking for a board that will be good enough that I can upgrade perhaps later from 12/16 gb of memory to possibly 24-32. (even though it's overkill I know :D)
If you have any other thoughts on the specs the motherboard should have feel free to list them as well. I don't claim to be an expert or anything.

item.description:

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:30, topic:515703”][quote author=Jmood link=topic=633960.msg4281818#msg4281818 date=1365729478]
If you need more ports you can also buy USB hubs. But with most mother boards coming with at least 3-5 ports alone why would you need one with more.
[/quote]he’s one of these noobs who has usb’s for everything…
rabbit tv, … internet, blah blah blah etc etc[/quote]

Then a hub should be no problem, you can also buy a PCI card with extra USB ports these days.

http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16815124118

Not to bad, quite cheap also.

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:25, topic:515703”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=633960.msg4281623#msg4281623 date=1365707380]
Corsair tend to do solid cases, can’t go wrong with them.

It’s possible to use 2.5 inch drives yes, you may have to buy mounting brackets so they don’t wobble around in the case though, also with a newer build you can’t not get an SSD…
[/quote]I really want to be able to utilize all of my usb ports(as my brother has several usb objects. Just from a quick corsair search on newegg they didn’t seem to have one with more than 5 usb slots. Any other brands that are solid?

this is the corsair that I saw.

http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811139017

let me know if it isn’t any good etc etc[/quote]
You realise they’re only the ports on the front right? I only have two USB 3.0 on my case, but there’s about 11 around the back on the motherboard sticking out… Why would you want to have loads of things plugged in the front anyway?

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

If it’s by a good brand (which means decent parts that don’t break etc), fits your motherboard and expansions, then you really can’t go wrong when getting a case. Just find one that you like that looks good

I got this one recently, http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16811156272 and has audio jacks and 3 more usb ports (1x3.0 2x2.0) Case looks great, has lots of room, and great cable management. It comes with cable ties etc, and allows you to feed the cables through the back of the case so you can’t see them. Fits mobo and card (660) perfect.

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

I wonder if there is a board that could hold 3 x titans…xD

but no seriously thanks for advice. Still going to play it safe though with the 850w. The electric bill really doesn’t bother me much, and as far as I know there isn’t a difference in 750w in 850w in the sense of “damaging the board” I don’t ever see myself going hardcore gamer so yeah one card is plenty.

So…now onto cases! Suggestions? What to look for when purchasing them? Also, is it possible to use an old hard drive from like a laptop or something?

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Wouldn’t advise it best off just getting one powerful card instead of three fairly average ones, besides, it’s unlikely you’ll be able to fit three in that motherboard.

Even so, 750W would be absolutely fine, I have that same PSU except the 750W version and I’m running a GTX 680

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

I may purchase two more graphic cards later ( just for the heck of it later but no time soon ) so I think I will keep a 850w. If you can find a better 850w though let me know. Corsair I know is a really good brand. Oh and sadly i pay the bills

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:19, topic:515703”]hmm okay…

so this is an update sort of. Changed the board/graphics card

Motherboard: 134.99$
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16813157293
Graphics Card: 179.99$
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814130910
CPU: 329.99$(little high on newegg may price around on!)
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819116501
Power Supply: 169.99$
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817139015
Memory: 119.99$
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820233380

Total cost before tax etc: 934$ ( not too bad… )

So …love it if you guys could double check everything to make sure all of that is compatible or explain to me how haha.

Guess now all I need is to find a case… and a fan…

Edit: er I assume all I need is a case fan? no heatsinks etc?[/quote]

To be fair you’d be perfectly fine with the i5 3570k, the i7 3770k is overpowered compared to the graphics card so there would be no real (noticeable) performance benefit of getting the 3770k.

Swap the RAM with this:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820233299
Much higher rated, reliable and a very well known choice amongst PC builders, including me :o

Swap the PSU with this:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16817139016&Tpk=ax750&IsVirtualParent=1
As I said before, 850W is way too much for that build, you may or may not pay the electric bills but even so, it’s just power that’s not ever going to be used. You’d be perfectly fine with 550W but I just linked the 750W just in case you were ever to add another graphics card.

The heatsink (comes with the fan, and thermal paste) is included with the 3770k and is perfectly adequate, so no need to buy an additional fan unless you’re doing a bit of overclocking.

Read full topic

Total cost before tax etc: 934$ ( not too bad… )

So …love it if you guys could double check everything to make sure all of that is compatible or explain to me how haha.

Guess now all I need is to find a case… and a fan…

Edit: er I assume all I need is a case fan? no heatsinks etc?
I mean to ask I just need a regular fan or do I need a fan that connects to the heatsink directly?

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Jmood:

I suggest a 850W. That should cover everything and give you some leg room if you wish to add something new later on.

Unnecessary, I can run 32gb RAM, i7 3770k, 2 GTX 680’s in SLI and 3 hard drives on my 750W modular PSU and still have plenty of room to breathe.

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:17, topic:515703”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=633960.msg4281563#msg4281563 date=1365698838]
The i7-3820 will not work with that sabertooth board. They have different sockets. The i7-3770 will work though
[/quote]ah I didn’t notice that

seems the 3820 is for a newer board or something?

Would it be better to just upgrade to a better board or go for the 3770[/quote]
Not necessarily newer, the 3820 came out many months before the 3770k, my friend has the 3820 and I’d definitely still take the 3770k over it, 3770k scores higher on benchmarks, it doesn’t have the triple channel memory limitation (you would have to buy RAM in sets of 3), and in general the choice in hardware you can choose (with heat sinks, motherboards etc) is quite limited, due to the ‘odd’ socket type.

Oh and don’t get the 3770, get the the 3770k.

GTX 660 is a decent card, but if you’re looking for something slightly cheaper with almost no drop in performance definitely take a look at the GTX 650 BOOST, newly released a couple of weeks ago.

Liquid cooling would also be unnecessary, what you have so far would have no problem running on air, water cooling is a lot of hassle.

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:9, topic:515703”]Buy a quad core i5/i7
a mother board with the socket to match it (Pretty much all modern mother boards hold at least 32gb of RAM, and have all the PCI/E slots that you need, as long as you pick an ATX or a Micro ATX).

and then a video card like this: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16814130809[/quote]

SilentCJ:

Highly recommend that cpu as I have it, I have the Asus Sabertooth Z77 and it’s been lovely so you could take a look at that

okay…so that z77 does look pretty sweet from what I am reading just need to make sure this processor works with it?

http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16819115229

was thinking about getting that video card660ti that somebody posted.

So …

660ti - (plus highest warranty)
z77 - (plus highest warranty)
i73820 - (plus highest warranty)
corsair 2x8 gb - ( http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16820233246 ) (plus highest warranty) Somebody please double check this is the right memory I think it is it did mention 1600 which was on the motherboard I believe?

now another question… what type of power wattage(or what exactly tells me what is required?)
with this setup would I need a large tower or what?
do you suggest liquid cooling or just a regular fan?

Edit: wow…haven’t even hit 1k$ yet lol

Read full topic

item.title: Motherboard
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:11, topic:515703”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=633960.msg4281315#msg4281315 date=1365635643]
Highly recommend that cpu as I have it, I have the Asus Sabertooth Z77 and it’s been lovely so you could take a look at that
[/quote]that does look pretty cool. I like the 3.0 port amounts as well. Stupid question…can you use 2.0 - usb items in the 3.0 still?[/quote]

Yes, 3.0 is backwards compatible with 2.0.
